column5: Symmetry in Introductory Mechanics
column18: Conservation laws are powerful tools of physics. Noether's theorem uses symmetry properties of Nature to provide a deep justification for conservation laws. For example, invariance under translation in time leads to the law of conservation of energy. Such symmetry arguments in classical mechanics are typically developed using high-level mathematics, which delays their introduction until advanced mechanics classes. However, the corresponding physical ideas are much easier to understand than the mathematical derivations. Applying non-traditional but elementary symmetry arguments to a few real examples allows us to introduce the relation between symmetry and conservation in first-year mechanics classes.

column5: Physics for Elementary Teachers: A New Curriculum*
column15: Fred M. Goldberg, San Diego State Univ.
column18: With support from NSF we have developed a one-semester research-based Physics for Elementary Teachers (PET) course that focuses on achieving four main goals: physics content, nature of science, elementary students' ideas, and learning about learning. During the 2003-2004 academic year the curriculum has been piloted at six Universities. In this talk I will briefly describe the curriculum, focusing on the conceptual, nature of science, and learning about learning components. I will also share some preliminary evaluation data. Next year we expect PET to be field-tested at about 25 Universities and two-year colleges. Information about the PET curriculum is available at

column5: Audio Analysis in a Physics of Music Course
column18: A series of talks for the general public on the technical aspects of music and instruments has developed into a course on the physics of music. I have used Vernier's Sound program, now packaged in LabPro, to illustrate why different instruments and instrument groups have different sounds. Sound samples of each instrument are taken and a harmonic analysis is performed. Instrument groups tend to have similar harmonic content within their group but different content among the groups. These analyses will be discussed along with explanations of why they occur. Suggestions will be made for including this analysis in talks for the public and beginning physics courses.

column5: Using Computers as Interactive Problem-Solving Coaches
column18: As more powerful computers become available, they can play an important role in physics instruction by coaching students to develop good problem-solving skills. Building on previous research on the teaching of problem solving and on computer-student interactions, we are designing computer tutorials that provide students with guided practice in solving problems. We will present a prototype of such a tutorial along with students reactions to it and discuss some of the design issues identified.

column5: In the Trenches: The Challenge of First-Year Physics
column18: The student transition from high school to college is hard enough for an instructor without the challenge of correcting the student's preconceived notions about the physical universe. In addition to teaching the principles of physics, instructors of first-year physics students must grapple with a host of issues ranging from math to critical thinking and problem solving skills. A discussion of the challenges and possible solutions will take place in an effort to help instructors develop successful methodologies for engendering student success.

column5: Vacuum Cannon Velocity Limit
column15: Eric Ayars, California State Univ., Chico
column18: What is the maximum velocity of a projectile shot from a vacuum cannon? It's commonly assumed that the speed of sound is an upper limit, but the theoretical maximum velocity turns out to be quite a bit less than that. The maximum velocity is independent of any parameters of the vacuum cannon, such as diameter and projectile mass. This poster describes the theory, assumptions made in deriving the closed-form solution, and experimental measurements that support the theory as an upper limit.

column18: This poster will contain various community highlights, students' awards, pictures, etc. pertaining to the Rose State College Physics program. Many of the correct or distracting legends refer to sports, energy and environmental issues, biology etc. The test is designed to measure universal skills that should be the lasting result of an education in physics and related fields and is a challenge in scientific thinking. The main idea could be used at other levels and in other areas. The talk presents several such examples I have designed.

At the University of Washington, the Physics Education Group has been developing research-based tutorials to supplement traditional instruction in textbooks, lectures, and labs. column5: Students' Mental Models and Beliefs About Circular Motion*
column15: Yeounsoo Kim, The Ohio State Univ.
column17: Gyoungho Lee, Jiyeon Park, Lei Bao
column18: Students can create on the spot mental models to deal with the demands of specific problem-solving situations. These models have important information about how the students construct the representations of the physical world and change their knowledge. This research is a study for developing learning strategy considering students' mental models. The purpose of this study is to investigate high school students' mental models and beliefs about circular motion, and to find out epistemological and ontological presuppositions related to the beliefs. To conduct this research, we developed an instrument for identifying student's mental models and interviewed two participants with this tool. We will present the characteristics of the metal models and the process of the development of the instrument and discuss the reasons why teachers should consider students' mental models and beliefs when they design instruction.

column5: Developing Instruments for Evaluating Anxiety Caused by Cognitive Conflict
column15: Yeounsoo Kim, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: Physics learning situations often involve many cognitive conflicts between a student's present understandings and new information being learned. Cognitive conflict is known as an important factor in conceptual change. Therefore, it is important to help physics teachers and students develop skills and knowledge for more effective conflict management. However there is no readily available method by which to identify the types of meaningful (constructive) cognitive conflict that students may have in their learning. We focus the study on the student anxiety caused by cognitive conflict so that we can improve student motivations in learning. This study is targeted to develop an easy-to-use instrument that can be implemented in classroom to monitor students' status of their anxiety in cognitive conflict situations and the effects on students' motivations in learning.

column5: Model Rocketry in the 21st Century Physics Classroom
column18: Model rocketry is an effective way to teach physics and engineering concepts to high school students. The theoretical physics that describes the flight of a model rocket can be accessible to these students. An Excel spreadsheet with basic physics equations can be used to predict a theoretical flight of a model rocket. This prediction can also be detailed and modeled, using simulation software such as RockSim. Electronic flight data recorders are readily available and can collect motion information during an actual rocket flight. This data can then be compared to the theoretical models. Students enjoy designing, building, testing and modifying model rockets, both as in-class activities and in extra-curricular competitions such as the Team America Rocketry Challenge, sponsored by the National Association of Rocketry and the Aerospace Industries Association.

column5: A Summary of the Effects of Question Order*
column17: N. Sanjay Rebello, Dean A. Zollman
column18: Developing accurate assessment tools is critical if we are to continue to expand our knowledge of student understanding. Test development often relies on the assumption that student knowledge is unaffected by the test or by the order of questions on the test. The results of this study call into question this assumption. This study used multiple choice mechanics questions taken from the Force Concept Inventory in both large class survey and interview situations with introductory physics students. Our analysis shows that question order can have a statistically significant effect on student responses and these effects can influence student scores on these surveys. This talk will also draw on some of the current theories of transfer to provide explanations for the observed effects.

Larger area fractions lead to an increase in the correlation length as well as the magnitude of the underlying particle-particle correlations.

We have explored the different ways students orient to, interpret, and participate in MBL. Traditional taxonomy of laboratory instruction styles often suggests that there is a dichotomy between a lab being structured and being open inquiry. However in our study we question this dichotomy and we will from our empirical data show that students' courses of action in some dimensions are framed by encounters with the instructions, the technology, the teacher, and other peers wile they in other dimensions are free to explore. Therefore we propose that MBL-tasks could best be described as being both highly structured in some aspects and open inquiry in other.

column5: Attending the 2003 ICPS and Studies of Single Quantum Wells
column18: This past summer I was fortunate enough to represent the Society of Physics Students (SPS) at the International Conference for Physics Students (ICPS) in Odense, Denmark. Every year SPS gives out the Outstanding Undergraduate Student Research Award. This award includes a seat as a delegate at the annual meeting for IAPS as well as an invited talk at the ICPS. column5: Assessment Analysis -- Statistical Analysis for Teachers
column15: Aaron P. Titus, High Point Univ.
column18: Physics education research, for many high school and college teachers, is a simple form of action research. As teachers, we try to ascertain what we are teaching and what students are learning (in our classroom), and we seek to make improvements, perhaps implementing a new teaching strategy or incorporating a new curriculum. Assessment of teaching effectiveness is often quantitative and requires statistical analysis. We may give a pretest and posttest or look for correlations between measures of student achievement. Assessment analysis is a free, web-based application that helps teachers calculate normalize gain, effect size, correlation coefficients, and factor analysis. After seeing Assessment Analysis, you'll never want to use Excel again!

column5: Secondary Science in the "Bush," 40 Years Ago
column15: James Lehman, James Madison Univ. - Retired
column18: Secondary science instruction in Northern Rhodesia/Zambia in the 1960s required a degree of resourcefulness. At Chipembi Secondary Girls School, the science department had limited demonstration equipment, and no commercial electricity was available. The school year went with the calendar year of three equal 12-week terms. British texts and examinations were used. Important student goals were directed to passing the "school leaving" examinations after the Third and Fifth Forms. Teaching was topical in nature, and the challenge for the teacher was to relate learning to everyday village life as the students prepared for the final examinations. Concepts of physics and chemistry were usually alternated term by term. Physics instruction was given to separate areas of matter and energy, motion, heat, sound, magnetism and electricity. Modest attempts were made in problem solving. By 1968, Nuffeld and several other British curricula were on the horizon with some unifying themes.

column5: Modes of Vibration of a Tennis Racket and Interactions with a Tennis Ball
column18: Vibrational modes of a tennis racket, determined by experimental modal testing, can be divided into two categories: one in which the motion is dominated by the frame, and one in which the motion is dominated by the strings. Composite and wide-body rackets tend to have high stiffness and modal damping. The dwell time and coefficient of restitution of a tennis ball were measured for three cases: 1. impact with a hard surface; 2. the racket clamped; 3. the racket handle clamped. Some implications of the results for tennis players and designers of tennis equipment are discussed.

column5: Environmental Noise Control
column18: Noise affects people in many ways. In addition to causing temporary and permanent hearing loss, noise interferes with speech communication, interrupts sleep, and reduces human efficiency. We have come to recognize the importance of good classroom acoustics. Students deserve to understand the teacher and each other. Only recently have standards for classroom acoustics been developed by professional organizations.

column5: The WYP 2005 - An Opportunity to Increase the Public's Awareness and Appreciation of Physics
column17: Warren W. Hein, Gary D. White
column18: The year 2005 marks the 100th anniversary of Einstein's "miraculous year" in which he published four important papers describing ideas that have since influenced all of modern physics. The year provides the opportunity to celebrate Einstein, his great ideas, and his influence on life in the 21st century. The World Year of Physics (WYP 2005) is a worldwide celebration of physics and its importance in everyday lives. The goal of the WYP is to raise the public awareness of physics and physical science and this presentation will share what the American Physical Society, American Association of Physics Teachers, and the American Institute of Physics/Society of Physics Students are doing to promote the WYP 2005.

column5: Big Science and Strong Medicine - The Lawrence Brothers' Legacy in Nuclear Science and Medicine
column15: Margaret McMahan, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory
column18: Ernest Lawrence can be considered the father of "Big Science." His work at U.C. Berkeley earned him the Nobel prize in Physics in 1939 for the invention of the cyclotron and led to the establishment of the Radiation Laboratory in the hills above the campus, now Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Lesser known are the contributions of his brother John, who joined Ernest in Berkeley in the early years and established a medical program at the new cyclotrons. The two fields of nuclear science and nuclear medicine - both diagnostic and therapeutic - are integrally linked to this day.

column5: The Navigator - Clickers on Steroids
column18: How one group is trying to cope with modeling and high stakes testing by using the Navigator wireless assessment system to push and listen to students. How can we know what kids know and then point them to the Truth while preparing for assessments that "seem" to be knowledge level interactions with our curriculum?

column5: Learning Physics Through Project-Based Assessments: Engaging Instruction for Non-Science Majors
column18: Many students enrolled in non-science majors at two-year colleges must complete general education requirements that include introductory physics courses. Making physics courses relevant and engaging presents a considerable challenge for the teacher. Students' epistemic beliefs regarding physics learning, lack of appropriate background knowledge and a deeply rooted set of misconceptions all contribute to poor performance and low motivation. I will outline a project-based assessment approach designed to help students make connections between qualitative knowledge and its applicability to real world situations. Initial results indicate an improvement in conceptual understanding and increased awareness of the significant role of physics concepts in everyday events.

column5: 1930's New York City High School Physics: Crucible of the Future
column18: The evolution of Stuyvesant High School from a trade school to an early science magnet school set the stage for the development of the modern high school physics syllabus and science magnet schools in general, including the Bronx High School of Science. The role of the principal, Ernest von Nodroff and other influential Stuyvesant faculty will be discussed, as well as the nature of the new 1930's Regents physics curriculum, largely developed by Stuyvesant faculty.

column5: VideoPoint Analysis of Bicycle Gear Ratios
column15: Chuck Stone, North Carolina A&T; State Univ.
column18: VideoPoint is a video analysis software package for Macintosh and Windows based computers that allows one to collect position and time data from digital video images in the form of "video points." This presentation will describe a VideoPoint project that investigates how a bicycle's speed depends on the pedaling gear. The gear ratio dictates how much power a cyclist can transmit to the rear wheel of a bike. Two different methods will be used to measure gear ratios. The first method determines the gear ratio by simply counting the number of teeth on the driver and driven gears. The second method determines the gear ratio by using VideoPoint to measure the angular speeds of the pedals and rear wheel. Both methods yield consistent results. The extensive use of technological tools, computer software, and data analysis routines makes this project a viable activity for undergraduate physics students.

column5: Fysik Lasershow: 10 Years of Outreach, How It Is Done and the Resulting Impact
column18: One of the main goals for The World Year of Physics 2005 is to connect the general public with physics and how developments in physics surrounds us in our everyday life. For eight years we have been marketing physics to young students and general audiences with a show that features 45 minutes of demonstrations and an artistic 15 minute laser show. Originally set-up in the main lecture hall of the Physics Department, the laser display is mostly built from physics education apparatus such as gratings, rotating mirrors, oscillating springs, etcetera. We now also pack up the show and travel to science festivals and public gatherings resulting in a total of 70 shows, each with an audience of around 200. We have an improved situation of students enrolling for studying physics in Lund and we think the shows may have had an impact on our recruitment.

column5: Physics Teacher Development at a Rural School in South Africa
column18: In South Africa many physics teachers' content knowledge is not strong and their schools are very poorly resourced, often lacking running water, electricity, laboratories, textbooks or even enough desks and chairs. Through the Center for the Improvement of Mathematics, Science and Technology Education, we are involved in the professional development of such teachers using distance education. In this paper we will present a case study of one teacher from a deep rural area and his development over the past two years. We shall first describe his school and then present our professional development model. We shall illustrate the impact of this model by showing how the teacher's content knowledge, teaching skills and professional attitudes have improved over the two years he has been enrolled as our student.

column5: Students' Perception of an Atom*
column17: Bekir Oruncak, Huseyin A. Yalim, Ismet Dogan
column18: Students' perception of an atom have been investigated through a written questionnaire. We looked the ways students describe an atom and its relation to matter and energy. A total of 919 students from eight different high schools and Afyon Kocatepe University participated in the survey. The collected data through a written questionnaire were analyzed using the phenomenographic method.
column19: *Supported by AKU- Scientific Research Committee, Grant# 022-FENED.10

column5: Interactive Lecture Demonstrations in the Introductory Physics Class in Japan
column15: Michi Ishimoto, Kochi Univ. of Tech.
column18: Interactive Lecture Demonstrations by R.K Thornton and D.R. Sokoloff was introduced in the introductory physics classes with traditional lectures in Japanese. The students were mainly biology, chemistry, and material engineering majors. Force and Motion Conceptual Evaluation examinations were given before and after the course. The exam result has shown that high school physics education has not improved the understanding of physics concepts for most students. The result of the exams will be compared with those in the United States. A major problem for ILD was the passive student attitude to participation in discussion.

column5: First Year Physics and Experimental Seminar Course; Lund University, Sweden
column18: In our program at Lund University the first year physics course is a one semester full time course. Advantages of this program will be discussed. The term concludes with an experimental seminar course that runs for seven days of full time work for the students. Here the students decide on an experimental topic and work in pairs coached by three instructors. In the course the students learn how to develop an experiment of their own design. They learn about the methodology of research and how to proceed when something goes wrong. The course process and samples of student projects will be presented. This popular course provides a way for students to really feel that they are a part of the Physics Department.

column5: Assessing Transfer of Conceptual Understanding
column18: A project is underway at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in which tools and techniques are being developed to assess the transfer of conceptual understanding developed in introductory physics and calculus courses to higher level engineering courses. This project, which is funded under the NSF-CCLI Assessing Student Achievement program, will be described in this talk. The tools under development will be presented as will preliminary data sets. The research on transfer of understanding that informed the project design will be discussed as well.

column5: Do We Say What We Mean? Misclassification of Physics Concepts and Students' Difficulties
column18: Physicists understand that the word "heat" refers to a process through which a system can gain or lose energy. But is this understanding reflected in the way physicists write and talk about heat? I will analyse references to "heat" in three popular introductory college physics textbooks, and introduce a simple coding scheme. This coding scheme will be used to classify references to "heat" as either "substance" based or "process" based. I will also code student's reasoning about the concept of "heat" with the same coding scheme. I will argue that both physicists' writing about and students understanding of "heat" is predominantly substance based.

column5: Inspirational Ideas for Teaching from
column18: Do you like wearing strange hats and make-up? Then you should go to Broadway, alternatively you could come to this talk. Wherein will be described an enjoyable and cheap way to teach the photoelectric effect using several different childrens toys. There will also be presented some ideas about teaching about infra-red, visible and ultraviolet parts of the electromagnetic spectrum. This will include using an ohp to produce a spectrum, a camera and a piece of Perspex to show infrared and make-up to demonstrate ultraviolet. Your pupils may never view you in the same light again! These ideas and many more have appeared in the journal

column5: Challenges of Teacher Education for Physics Departments
column18: In physics teacher education one of the challenges is to promote the development of expertise needed from physics teachers. In that close collaboration between physicist and physics education professionals is needed. This, however, poses many challenges which are not easily met. We describe here some guidelines, based on our own experience from a course for pre-service physics teacher education, how these challenges can be met by designing a course, which takes into attention the aspect of expertise expected from physics teachers. The positive results and feedback received is discussed.

column5: The Institute of Physics UK - The Teacher Network
column18: The Teacher Network In the UK the Institute of Physics is developing a Teacher Network where 30 Coordinators spread across Wales, England, Scotland and Ireland will support the teaching of Physics at a local level. This poster reports some of the many different ways in which the coordinators have filled their roles which in turn highlights many of the problems that need to be overcome in physics teaching today.

column5: Implementing Effective Model-Based Instruction
column15: Patrick Hession, Univ. of California, Davis
column18: We are in a continuing process of reforming the introductory physics course for biological science majors based on the results of educational research. One approach to the challenge of improving student analytical thinking is to organize course content and presentation around models. Models are arguably the principal product and methodology of science and are useful for answering questions, because they exclude extraneous issues and have a simplified internal logic. We have discovered that in spite of organizing the course around models, and directly teaching students how to use models, most tend to fall back into old habits of answering questions by, for example, grabbing the first apparently relevant equation and plugging in values. To reach our goals, we now believe it is necessary to modify the way we ask questions so that students cannot avoid explicitly using the model. We give examples of this approach.

column5: Connecting the Dots: Using Tracker's Visualization Tools to Link Models with Reality
column18: Every physics teacher knows the importance of visualization and problem-solving tools (graphs, vectors, animations, etc.) for helping students make the connection between observations and mathematical models. Existing video analysis programs generally do an excellent job of plotting and fitting measured data, but lack vector representations and model animation overlays. I will demonstrate some of the visualization tools being developed for Tracker, a free Java video analysis program built on the Open Source Physics framework. These include linkable force, net force and motion vectors, spectral line profiles, interactive model overlays and more. Tracker can be downloaded from

column5: Summative Report on Studio Physics at Rensselaer
column18: The Studio Physics program at Rensselaer was funded in part by an NSF- CCLI Adaptation and Implementation grant. In this talk I will outline the status of Studio Physics program at the start of the grant period, at the end of the grant period and now; approximately one year later. Assessments of student conceptual learning were preformed in every semester of the grant period. These assessment results will be summarized, as will student reactions to the course as measured with surveys.

column5: Luck Versus Control: Does Introductory Physics Affect Student Beliefs?*
column17: Vince Kuo, Thomas Thaden-Koch, Patricia Heller, Kenneth Heller
column18: It has been proposed that student attitudes and beliefs about learning physics are affected, mostly adversely, by experiences in introductory physics.
column19: *Supported in part by the University of Minnesota and NSF grant #DUE-9972470.

column5: Creation of Multimedia Textbook for Contextually-Relevant Introductory Course*
column18: The Science of Information Technology (ScIT) introduces students to physics principles critical to the operation of information technology. The course has been offered as an elective at Renssealer since 1999, with materials delivered through WebCT. Students from all disciplines have completed the course; the vast majority of them have demonstrated both enjoyment and learning. ScIT covers a wide range of physics topics, blending traditionally-covered topics like capacitance with topics like quantum-mechanical tunneling that are often omitted from traditional physics courses. The course is structured around four facets of how Information Systems work: Information Transfer, Information Storage, Information Processing, and Future Information Technologies. Our NSF-CCLI grant has enabled the conversion of many course materials into a form useful by other institutions, along with the study of student preconceptions of topics covered by the course. This talk will demonstrate the available materials and provide results of evaluations of student learning and attitude.
column19: *RPI work supported in part by NSF CCLI Program under grant DUE-0089399 1. See

column5: Student Learning of Quantum Mechanics*
column15: Homeyra Sadaghiani, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: Quantum physics is an abstract topic that not only deals with the inaccessible venues and concepts of the microscopic world, but also requires a certain degree of mathematical skill. In this study, we aim to determine the most important skills and concepts that can enhance students? performance in a quantum mechanics class. We would like to know, for example, if a relationship exists between particular math skills and understanding of quantum mechanics. In this talk we will discuss the research findings with specific examples.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grant #REC-0087788 and #REC-0126070.

column5: Effects of In-Class Polling on Student Performance in Learning Physics
column15: Pengfei Li, The Ohio State Univ., Columbus
column18: At The Ohio State University, Voting Machine (VM), an in-class polling system was used as a lecture instrument to teach students in an introductory electromagnetism class. A sequence of three questions (basic, intensive, extensive) was chosen as a useful tool to trigger the student into different learning modes. Using the voting machine, both the instructor and the students got instant interactive feedback during the teaching-learning activities. Initial results show that students using VM had better scores on relevant examination questions than students in other sections of the same course that didn't use VM. Further analysis is conducted to explore the relationships between the students' in-class polling data and their progress in learning. In this talk, we will discuss how the instant feedback works and the potential models that we aim to extract.

column5: Why Do I Have to Keep My Elbow In?
column18: "Keep yor elbow in." "Keep your feet apart." "Don't let the ball touch your palm." These and other coaching points are awkward and unfamiliar for any 11 year-old just learning to play basketball. They make sense to the coach because they work and they work because of physics. This paper briefly reviews physical principles behind the awkward bio-mechanics of the jumpshot and presents new insights into how the body learns to transform these awkward movements into a fluid precise and effective routine.

column5: Are Students Good at Choosing Representational Formats for Problem Solving in Physics?*
column15: Patrick Kohl, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder
column18: Student problem-solving ability appears to be tied to the representational format of the problem (mathematical, pictorial, graphical, verbal).

column5: Improving Introductory Physics Laboratories with Virtual Reality Simulations*
column15: Dedra Demaree, The Ohio State Univ.
column17: Stephen Stonebraker, Wenhui Zhao, Lei Bao
column18: The Ohio State University (OSU) Physics Department is modifying the current introductory calculus based physics laboratories to include Virtual Reality (VR) experiments developed by the PER group at OSU. Traditionally students are not enthusiastic about the laboratories and are often frustrated with inaccurate measurements and poor agreement with expected numerical results. Providing VR simulations allows for an ideal environment for studying specific processes with precise results. Mixing hands-on experiments with VR simulations allows for practical discussions of errors and approximations, as well as provides the opportunity for relating fast and/or intermolecular processes with easily observable events. As an added benefit, the joystick controlled VR experiments resemble interactive video games which increase student interest. With the inclusion of VR simulations, the laboratories can be more challenging and educational while also providing fun for the students. Preliminary results of student reactions to the VR experiments will be presented.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grants #REC-0087788 and #REC-0126070.

column5: Teaching and Learning in a Tanzanian Physics Class
column15: Danielle B. Harlow, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder
column18: In this presentation, I will discuss the Tanzanian school system particularly as it relates to physics education and describe my experiences teaching high school physics in a rural government school in Tanzania, East Africa. The secondary school physics curriculum is determined by an extensive national syllabus and a comprehensive national exam at the conclusion of secondary studies. Schools lack the funds to buy textbooks, lab equipment or even enough desks for all of the students. And yet, through creativity and determination, teachers teach and students learn in Tanzanian physics classrooms. I will describe my experiences teaching physics and working with local science teachers. I will talk about what I learned about teaching and learning from my Tanzanian students and fellow teachers.

column5: An Example of Virtual Reality Experiments in Introductory Physics Laboratories
column15: Dedra N. Demaree, The Ohio State Univ.
column17: Stephen Stonebraker, Wenhui Zhao, Lei Bao
column18: The Ohio State University (OSU) Physics Department is modifying the current introductory calculus based Physics laboratories to include Virtual Reality (VR) experiments developed by the PER group at OSU. The new laboratories combine physical equipment which gives hands-on experience with simulations which provide an ideal environment for studying specific processes in detail. The VR experiments allow for detailed study of fast processes which otherwise would not easily be visualized. An example of this is the new Impulse-Momentum laboratory. The VR collisions software shows the forces and resulting deformation of two carts during a collision. This leads to student exploration of momentum conservation directly from Newton's third law. Students not only confront cognitive conflicts about forces but also develop a deeper understanding of momentum conservation. This poster will present the value of incorporating VR simulations with specific examples from the Impulse-Momentum laboratory.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grants #REC-0087788 and #REC-0126070.

column5: Student Attitudes Towards Laboratory Quizzes
column15: Dedra Demaree, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: The Ohio State University Physics Department recently introduced laboratory quizzes in the introductory calculus based Physics sequence in order to motivate student participation in the laboratory portion of the course. Previously the laboratories were graded solely on an attendance basis, with full points given regardless of the amount of student effort. The new laboratory quizzes provide an additional small component to each student's overall grade. Several quiz types were tested to find a format which maximizes their effectiveness as a learning tool while minimizing the students' dismay over the additional work load. A balance was found between providing enough points to motivate the students to participate while keeping the points low enough to maintain a non-competitive environment in which to learn during the laboratories. Student feedback was obtained through extensive interviews and an anonymous online survey. Student attitudes towards the new laboratory quizzes will be presented.

column5: Model Analysis as a Method for Cognitive Representation and Measurement*
column15: Lei Bao, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: This talk will give an overview of the fundamental ideas in developing the method of Model Analysis. The discussion will provide a step-by-step introduction on the procedures of applying Model Analysis in research and instruction. A number of newly develop computational methods and tools will be introduced with practical examples.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grants #REC-0087788 and #REC-0126070.

column5: Efforts in Experimental and Computational Modeling of the Learning Environment*
column15: Lei Bao, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: The learning environment of a classroom is a very complicated context that has many variables, many of which are difficult to be identified. The behavior of an individual student in such a learning environment is affected by both the individual's internal characters and the communications among the students and the instructors. To obtain theoretical understanding of such a complex system, we need new tools and methods that can capture the real time interactions among the individuals. In this talk, we will discuss our research efforts in developing methods to measure and analyze new forms of data such as student voices and physical motion and how such results can be modeled to extract information about the dynamics of the teaching and learning interactions.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grants #REC-0087788 and #REC-0126070.

column5: Design of an Electronics Kit Suitable for Integrated Lecture/Lab Courses
column15: Gordon P. Smith, Western Kentucky Univ.
column18: Western Kentucky University is creating an interactive physics curriculum for it's algebra-based physics courses, modeled after SCALE-UP. This experience prompted the design of an electronics kit that was compact, easy to transport, versatile, and inexpensive. The resulting kit utilizes off-the-shelf components allowing students to investigate a wide range of electrical and magnetic phenomena. The kit itself costs approximately $80, and a wide variety of accessories can be constructed for little additional cost. The advantages of the kit are many. Students use the same pieces of equipment over and over, gaining confidence in measurement abilities. The students may see inside the kit to trace connections. Electrical components are color-coded as to function. All accessories may be stored in an integral drawer, promoting ease of storage and distribution. The poster will present details of construction, and a kit will be provided for the curious.

column5: The Effect of Helium on the Human Voice: A Laboratory Activity*
column18: When we make vocalized sound, the larynx produces a fixed set of frequencies and the vocal tract filters the sound. The sound that is heard is a product of both of these effects. When air is replaced by helium in the lungs, an obvious and usually humorous change occurs in the sound quality. What produces the change? Does the larynx produce different frequencies, does the vocal tract filter differently, or is it some combination? We describe an activity in which students explore these questions using inexpensive sound editing software. This activity is part of a human-focused introductory physics course, developed as part of the Humanized Physics Project.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grant #DUE-0088780 and #DUE-0088712. 1. Humanized Physics Project co-PIs: Robert G. Fuller and Vicki L. Plano Clark, University of Nebraska - Lincoln, Nancy L. Beverly, Mercy College, and Beth Ann Thacker, Texas Tech University.

column5: Andes, An Intelligent Tutor for a Two Semester General Physics Course
column17: Donald J. Treacy, Robert N. Shelby, Kay G. Schulze, Kurt VanLehn
column18: Andes is an intelligent tutoring system that allows students to receive immediate feedback as they work homework problems. Previously, the range of topics addressed by Andes had been restricted to those normally covered in the first semester of a two-semester general physics course. This spring the coverage has been expanded significantly, to include many topics in introductory electricity and magnetism including forces on charges due to E- and B-fields, electric potential, Faraday's Law, a variety of circuits and lenses and mirrors. Specific examples of problems and the considerations involved in presenting them, as well as plans for future developments and distribution of Andes will be discussed.

column5: Magnet Falling Through a Pipe
column15: M. Hossein Partovi, California State Univ., Sacramento
column18: The demonstration of a magnet falling through the pipe is often used in elementary physics courses to introduce such concepts as Faraday's law of induction and Lenz's law. From there the rigor of development varies widely. Traditionally analytic solutions to the problem utilize several assumptions, producing results that vary significantly from experimental data. Here a more realistic model is developed treating the case of a uniformly magnetized, cylindrically symmetric permanent magnet moving non-relativistically inside an infinitely long conducting shell of arbitrary thickness. Numerical calculations are presented. The Mathematica code used is available from emorris@csus.edu.

column5: Student Understanding of Sound Propagation: Research and Curriculum Development
column15: Katherine Menchen, The Univ. of Maine
column18: Our ongoing research involves exploring student understanding of sound and sound phenomena as part of the process of developing instructional materials to improve student learning, especially among preservice teachers. Our current focus is on sound propagation. We have previously reported, based on responses to written questions, that the concepts of propagation and resonance are not functionally distinguished by many students.
column19: 1. K.VP. Menchen and J.R. Thompson, "Preservice teacher understanding of propagation and resonance in sound phenomena," accepted for publication in 2003 Phys. Educ. Res. Conf. Proc., K. Cummings, S. Franklin, J. Marx, Eds. (2004).

column5: Magnetic Spheres: A Resource for Teaching Many Physical Concepts
column15: Alois Adams, Univ. of Arkansas, Little Rock
column18: Magnetic spheres represent a relatively inexpensive tool for teaching, reinforcing, and assessing student understanding of several fundamental concepts in Introductory Physics, including (but not limited to) electricity and magnetism, forces and motion, and conservation of momentum and energy. Science supply vendors now offer a variety of rare earth magnets in the form of spheres. Sizes range from a few millimeters to a few centimeters in diameter. This presentation will first overview the various types of spheres that are available, present data on their typical values for magnetic moment and its variance within one shipment, then suggest a number of ways in which magnetic spheres can be exploited in traditional lecture and laboratory settings, as well as directed and open inquiry activities. Their application in a final capstone exercise that integrates many of the important ideas in Introductory Physics will also be illustrated. Results from several of these pedagogical applications will be presented.

column5: LivePhoto Physics Video Analysis Homework: A Preliminary Study
column15: Alicia R. Allbaugh, Rochester Institute of Tech.
column18: The LivePhoto Physics project is creating a web-based homework system that enables students to perform analysis of videos of physical phenomenon as part of a homework session. These homework sessions include some conceptual assessment as well as the video analysis laboratory activities and more traditional homework problems/questions. Pilot homework sessions have been assigned to calculus-based students at RIT. In addition, more traditional assessment measures after an assigned session have been collected. A brief overview of the system will be presented as well as some preliminary implications on its effectiveness.

column5: Using Learning Theories to Model Students' Conceptual Changes
column18: The explosion of data from careful observations of student learning in the past decade allows for (and asks for) organization and summary. The results should be both generally descriptive and specifically predictive. Researchers in the cognitive and learning sciences have done much work of use to the PER community. In this talk, I extend the "resources"
column19: 1. Hammer, D., "Student resources for learning introductory physics"

column5: Accurate Computation of Exact Pendulum Motion
column18: It is well known that a pendulum performs simple harmonic motion only in the limiting case of an infinitesimally-small amplitude. Many intermediate-level textbooks consider the large-amplitude case and derive the expression for the exact period of motion in terms of the complete elliptic integral. The latter is then left as something to be looked up in a table, or computed from its expansion as a power series in the amplitude. The fact that this integral can be computed through a centuries-old, trivially simple algorithm is so little appreciated that it could qualify as the best-[un]kept secret in computational work. The algorithm will be described, along with its extensions to compute the pendulum's angular position and velocity as functions of time. A computer program that computes these quantities to machine-limited precision will be made available.

column5: Creating Curriculum and Interactivity for Middle School integrated Science
column18: Looking for a little pizzazz for your applets or online applications? Ever thought that you have a great idea for a web-based lesson, but don't know where to start? Let us help you get started. ASPIRE has been creating interactive online labs and lessons for Integrated Science courses since 1997. Creating online content presents many challenges. With new technologies available online, ASPIRE has been able to use traditional production methods and adopted from industry methods and created new techniques to develop immersive labs. In this session, learn how the ASPIRE team creates their lessons from beginning to end. ASPIRE is the educational outreach program for the High Resolution Cosmic Ray Research group at the University of Utah. ASPIRE is funded by the National Science Foundation.

column5: Recursive mentoring: A graduate-student led program for physics majors
column18: We report on a mentoring program designed for undergraduate physics majors and implemented using an integrated approach that accomplishes multiple goals with low incremental cost. Partially in response to the SPIN-UP report*, a program was initiated to better integrate physics majors? into the physics department and extend their undergraduate preparation beyond coursework. The program was developed in consultation with local Society of Physics Students (SPS) members and offered under the auspices of UCSD?s SPS chapter. Program activities were designed and conducted by physics graduate student participants in UCSD?s Preparing Future Physics Faculty program, which itself is a mentoring program for physics graduate students. Thus, organizing the undergraduate mentoring program served as a practical and self-reflective experience for the graduate students involved. In this poster we describe the program, its outcomes, and the benefits of an integrated and recursive approach to mentoring.
column19: *National Task Force on Undergraduate Physics report on the Strategic Programs for Innovations in Undergraduate Physics project. http://www.aapt.org/Projects/ntfup.cfm

column5: Sun and Moon Watching in the Pueblo World
column15: Michael Zeilik, The Learning Zone, Inc.
column18: The Pueblo peoples in the U.S. Southwest have carried out sun and moon watching for ritual purposes for at least a thousand years. Such observations tie the sacred calendar to the rhythms of the sky. A high religious official (Sun Priest or Moon Watcher) has the authority and responsibility to keep these calendars and announce ceremonial dates ahead of time---he must forecast them. The anticipatory observations for accurate forecasting may, for example, be the location of sunrise points along the horizon. Because these are naked-eye observations, they can be brought into an introductory astronomy course, even large ones. They are most effective when done for a month or two outside of class, using the Pueblo context for motivation.

column15: Robert Brown, Case Western Reserve Univ.
column17: Matthew Finnerty, Kathleen A Harper, Alexandra Treat
column18: In two methods of physics education, Spiral Physics

column5: Navajo Astronomy
column15: Fred Begay, Los Alamos National Laboratory
column18: An ancient Navajo model on the origin of the universe will be described. The properties of this model are similar to the Big Bang model, which is described in modern astronomy. A module of Navajo bilingual lesson plans on space sciences, which is used in Navajo K-12 schools, will be described. The module is supported by computer animations that enhance the visualization and comprehension of concepts in astronomy.

column5: ASPIRE: Writing Flash Interactive Labs for Web-Based Learning
column18: Macromedia's Flash allows over 98% of web users access to highly immersive, interactive web content. While many of these creations are for advertising and entertainment purposes, Flash has a powerful object-oriented programming language that allows the ASPIRE team to create interactive, online lessons and labs. These virtual, hands-on activities allow students to "see and touch" labs that would be impossible or cost-prohibitive to do in the classroom. Join us to see how Flash technology can be incorporated into the physics and astronomy classroom for hands-on activities.

column5: Growth of Physics and its Influence on Public Policy after World War II
column18: Before World War II the American Public was hardly aware of physics. After the war it was regarded as a key component of American success and policy, but this was to fade somewhat in the latter part of the century. Interaction of the scientific community with the public and with government during these decades will be discussed with specific illustrations, along with the need for such interactions today.

column5: High School Activities and Achievement on the FCI and Force Problems
column18: Students in a large introductory physics class were given the FCI and a questionnaire about their high school activities at the beginning of the semester. Students were also asked which of their activities they thought would help them to learn physics. Relationships between these activities and scores on the FCI and on force problems given in later tests will be explored. Particular attention will be paid to whether sports experience or high school physics classes have any effect on FCI scores or test scores.

column5: Integrating Adaptable Tutorials with Professional Development Materials: Part 1
column17: Raymond A Hodges, Andrew R Elby
column18: Excellent PER-based materials exist; the main bottleneck to reform is implementation. So why are we developing new materials as part of our current project? In part one of this two-part talk, we explain how our materials are designed to facilitate their own implementation. First, our tutorials and ILDs are open-source, electronic documents; instructors can adapt them to the specific needs of their students. Second, to help faculty and TAs make effective adaptations and use the materials productively, we hyperlink the tutorials to instructors' guides that include the rationale behind the various questions, teaching tips, common student responses, and so on. Third, the instructors' guides also include annotated video clips of students using the materials. TAs and faculty can use these clips to get a feel for the lessons and to practice "hearing" and interpreting students' reasoning and conceptions in a way that can improve their teaching.

column5: Integrating Adaptable Tutorials with Professional Development Materials: Part 2
column17: Timothy L McCaskey, Andrew R Elby
column18: The previous speaker droned on and on about the new tutorials and professional development materials we are generating. In part two of this two-part talk, we now show you the materials and model how they could be used, for instance, as part of a TA-preparation seminar.

column5: What Counts as Convincing? Examples from Physics and Physics Education
column15: Nicole Gillespie, Knowles Science Teaching Foundation
column18: In 1905, at a time when some scientists refused to accept the existence or even scientific propriety of the atom, Einstein's explanation of Brownian motion in terms of kinetic theory was widely regarded as convincing proof that atoms actually existed. In this talk I discuss the impact of Einstein's Brownian motion work on physics as well as on notions of what is considered convincing in science. I also present research on how undergraduate students use the idea of gas particles in their discussions of thermodynamic phenomena, focusing on what they establish as convincing in their discussions. I review the common difficulties that students have with this topic, emphasizing the contexts in which these difficulties arose. Both Einstein's work on Brownian motion and research on student understanding and use of particulate models of matter have important implications for how we view the nature of science and, consequently, how we teach science.

column5: Where's the PER Inspiration in the TIPERs?*
column15: David Maloney, Indiana Univ. Purdue Univ. Fort Wayne
column17: Curtis J. Hieggelke, Thomas L. O'Kuma, Stephen E Kanim
column18: We are in the process of developing a set of paper and pencil tasks called Tasks Inspired by Physics Education Research (TIPERs) that instructors can use to promote conceptual understanding and interactive engagement. The materials currently under development are in the domain of electricity and magnetism. Physics education research has influenced the materials being developed in several ways. There are direct influences such as taking a task format that has been used in a research study and writing electricity and magnetism items in that format. There are also indirect influences such as designing a task set around an issue identified by research or using student comments that present alternative conceptions in natural language just as the students usually do. This presentation will identify many of the physics education research activities/results that have influenced the TIPERs.
column19: *Supported in part by the NSF through grants #DUE-9952735 and #DUE-0125831.

column5: Automatically-Graded, Multiple-Representation Problem Solving
column18: Like it or not, automatic grading of introductory problem solutions is here to stay. However, homework grading systems that check only the answer do not encourage student practice of expert-like problem solving techniques, such as the multiple representations approach suggested by various physics education researchers. In this talk I will demonstrate a web-based automatic Problem Solving Evaluator (PSE) prototype, based on the multiple representations approach.

column5: Hypothesis-Based Learning at Oklahoma State University
column18: This presentation will address comparative studies conducted on Elementary Education majors at Oklahoma State University (OSU) during the 2003-4 academic year. Students were exposed to either McDermott's Physics By Inquiry curriculum or to Hypothesis-Based Learning (HBL), an instructional pedagogy developed by M.G. Rockley, et al., at OSU. HBL content was created to mirror four of McDermott's content areas: Astronomy by Sight, Light and Color, Heat and Temperature, and Electric Circuits. After one semester of instruction in these content areas, students were assessed using attitudinal, efficacy, process, and content instruments. A survey of selected results will be presented.

column5: Who Says How Far a Home Run Goes?
column15: William Sherwin, Case Western Reserve Univ.
column18: Great excitement and much discussion accompany long home runs in baseball. The debate centers on how far the home run has gone, which is complicated by the fact that home runs almost always hit something, such as a wall or a bleacher seat. The theoretical distance that a home run has gone must be estimated by extrapolation. It is recognized, however, that high fly balls or line drives extrapolate rather differently, especially if the obstruction was fairly high up in vertical distance. Different teams use different methods of extrapolation, such as a linear approximation, and supply different numbers depending upon a qualitative assessment of the trajectory height. To improve on these techniques, we use numerical methods to compute the trajectory, assessing the importance of spin, wind, altitude, and temperature (SWAT). A particularly interesting long home run hit by Mark McGwire, which hit high up on a scoreboard, is analyzed.

column5: High School Use of Microcomputer-Based Laboratories (MBL) in Learning Force and Motion: Issues of Implementation and Adaptation
column15: Randell Barclay, H.S. for Math, Science and Engineering
column18: The effectiveness of curriculum based on Physics Education Research (PER) is well-demonstrated for learning college-level physics. There is less research on the application of PER methods and results at the high school level. We report on the implementation of PER-inspired techniques in the laboratory section of a high school physics course. MBL activities from RealTime Physics (Sokoloff, Thornton and Laws; 1999) are used and student performance is assessed by pre- and posttests using the Force Concept Inventory (FCI) and Force and Motion Conceptual Evaluation (FMCE). We also report on issues of implementing and adapting PER results to the high school environment.

column5: When the Classroom Isn't School: PER for Social Inclusion in the Sciences
column15: Noah D. Finkelstein, Univ. of Colorado, Boulder
column18: This talk introduces the complementary side of a university-community collaboration, which has previously focused on a university course: Teaching and Learning Physics
column19: 1. N.D. Finkelstein, "Teaching and learning physics: A model for coordinating physics instruction, outreach, and research,"

column5: Institutional and Instructor Factors Affecting Implementation of Class Response Systems
column15: Edward P Price, Univ. of California, San Diego
column18: Electronic class response systems (CRS) facilitate the use of interactive techniques in large classes, and learning gains have been shown for CRS-based peer instruction and interactive demonstrations.

column5: The Introduction of Research-Based Physics Curricula at a Community College
column18: The attempts of a new science department faculty member to implement curricula based on Physics Education Research (PER) are reported. Materials from Physics by Inquiry and Interactive Lecture Demonstrations are used in a course of general physics for non-majors at a two-year college. Issues regarding the introduction of PER-based curricula into a preexisting non-research based system are discussed.

column5: Discipline-Based Educational Research at Arizona State University in Science and Mathematics
column18: The Center for Research on Education in Science, Mathematics, Engineering, and Technology (CRESMET) at Arizona State University promotes interdisciplinary educational collaborations to improve K-20 science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education. CRESMET uses discipline-based educational research to identify the gaps in STEM education that may impede students' success in science and mathematics. Through the alliance of ASU's Colleges of Education, Engineering and Applied Sciences, and Liberal Arts and Sciences, CRESMET supports initiatives from kindergarten to graduate school. I will describe my involvement in two related projects meant to integrate mathematics curriculum in science courses for in-service teachers and in introductory physics courses for science and engineering majors at Arizona State University.

column5: Preparing Math & Science Teachers at Amarillo College
column18: While critical shortages continue in the area of mathematics, physics, and the sciences in general, community colleges are beginning to fill the important role of preparing young future teachers, especially in the physical sciences. With emphasis on grants, collaboration with universities, and regional education service centers, progess is being made in the almost impossible task of training enough science teachers for the future. What kind of teachers are you preparing? The complete teacher education program and its link to physics and the Sciences & Engineering Division at Amarillo College will be reviewed. Successes and challenges will be discussed, as will the AAPT recognition as an exemplary program with the SPIN-UP/TYC site visit.

column5: Wave Packet Construction and Evolution in Asymmetric Infinite Square Wells*
column17: Mario Belloni, Michael A. Doncheski, Richard W Robinett
column18: Over the past few years a number of authors have been interested in the time evolution and revival of Gaussian wave packets in one-dimensional wells. For the standard infinite square well, the wave function is guaranteed to revive at a time proportional to the inverse of the system's ground-state energy. If the positioning of the packet is just right, revivals can also occur many times before the revival time. In this talk we will use our understanding of wave packets in an infinite square well to investigate packet behavior in an asymmetric infinite well: an infinite well with a constant potential energy "hump" covering part of its base. We will discuss how we determine the energy spectrum and wave functions of an asymmetric infinite well, and use these states to construct and analyze the time-dependent behavior of wave packets in such a well.
column19: *Supported by a Research Corporation Cottrell College Science Award (CC5470).

column5: Analysis of Class I Protostars Observed with the Spitzer Space Telescope
column15: Gail Zasowski*, Univ. of Tennessee - Knoxville
column18: The study of young stellar objects and their accompanying dust/gas envelopes and disks is a significant and rapidly growing area in the field of astrophysics. Using spectroscopic data from the new Spitzer Space Telescope, I analyzed several Class I protostellar sources to identify characteristics that could be used in modeling these objects. First, the spectra were extracted from the raw Spitzer data and put into usable format. Then each source was fitted with representations of the spectral continua; these were used to calculate optical depths of the major peaks and features. Plotting these data yielded several trends, such as the close correlation between H2O and CH3OH ices. Laboratory ice spectra were fit to the strong 15.2 (MU)m CO2 feature of some objects. The apparent crystalline structure of some of these CO2 features was studied.

column5: Use of Pre-Lab Technology in General Physics
column15: Karen A. Williams, East Central Univ.
column18: This paper will describe how I introduced Beyond Questions (BQ) prelab questions in my general physics course. It is qualitative in nature and will show the student's perspective of using pre-lab questions. Future plans for BQ in my classes will be discussed.

column5: A Blue Moon, Einstein, and Mie
column15: Michael Paesler, North Carolina State Univ.
column18: Einstein's doctoral dissertation applies to---among other phenomena---the motion of atmospheric aerosols. This motion can result in atmospheric sorting of a layer of particles with average radius r. The optical consequences of such sorting follow from straightforward application of Mie's theory regarding the scattering of electromagnetic radiation of wavelength l (lambda). As first discussed by W. Paul and R.V. Jones [Nature 169, 554 (1951)] when 0.8 l (lambda) < r < 1.1 l (lambda). Mie's theory predicts that extinction is a decreasing function of particle radius. Under this condition light of longer wavelength will be scattered more than light of shorter wavelength. This coupling of Einstein's work to Mie's theory thus leads to an explanation of a rare atmospheric phenomenon known as a blue moon.

column5: What Does the SPS President Do Anyway???
column15: Karen A Williams, East Central Univ.
column18: Many I speak with don't know what the President of the National Council actually does. This poster will show what I did and where I went in the service of SPS as President. Feel free to ask questions. We will be electing a president in 2005, and you could be the next SPS President. It has been an opportunity of a lifetime for me. I highly recommend you run for president of SPS---not the country!

column5: HS Physics: Continuing to Broaden the Base and Improve Instruction
column18: The high school physics classroom today contains a much wider mix of genders, races, cultures, and abilities than the classroom of the '60s. The "Physics First" and "Physics for All" initiatives have helped to accelerate this transformation. How have we changed our courses and our teaching in response to the conflicting demands for greater participation and higher achievement? How can we produce more scientifically literate citizens and continue to inspire more students to pursue careers in science or teaching?

column5: Incorporating Archaeoastronomy and Ethnoastronomy into an Astronomy Course
column18: Archaeoastronomy combines astronomy and archaeology, and uses physical artifacts to examine the astronomy of ancient peoples. Ethnoastronomy combines ethnology with astronomy. An ethnoastronomer is interested in myths, legends, religious belief, and ritual practices of pre-modern Native Americans. Incorporating what I have learned about these subjects into my astronomy courses shows students that Native Americans have a rich understanding of the night sky

column5: University Partnerships -- Developing Communities of Practice for Teachers' Professional Development
column15: Brent Duckor, UC Berkeley School of Education
column18: In conjunction with its No Child Left Behind Act, the Department of Education has charged school leaders with establishing university partnerships in order to ensure expert science instruction. Building communities of expert teachers begins with bringing together people with different strengths. Common to every community is the notion of a working group, or what we are calling a "Work Circle" at UC Berkeley's Graduate School of Education and the Lawrence Hall of Science. For over a year now, teachers, graduate students, curriculum developers, content experts, and educational researchers have been collaborating to develop an assessment system for the FOSS physics curriculum. In the process, participants are realizing the potential of the Work Circle through an exchange of knowledge about curriculum development, assessment and classroom teaching. The implications for teachers' professional development will be emphasized.

column5: The Dark Century: Matter, Energy, and the Future of the Universe
column18: Dark matter is a sort of shorthand for an enormous body of evidence indicating that most of the stuff in the universe neither emits nor absorbs its fair share of light. Some of the data go back more than 80 years, and there are hints its even earlier. Dark energy, also called quintessence, the cosmological constant, and even worse things, is both an integration constant in Einstein's equations and a similar shorthand. The database here is not quite so extensive or so deeply grounded in history, but still very persuasive, implying that the universe is as flat as general relativity allows and that its expansion is accelerating. There are droves of candidates for both dark matter particles and dark energy fields, though so far no laboratory detections of any. Something can, however, be said about their properties, which, in turn, determine the long-range future.

column5: Investigating Student Learning with Visualizations in a Physical Science Course*
column15: S. Raj Chaudhury, Norfolk State Univ.
column18: While visualizations of physical phenomena occupy a prominent place in textbooks for college science courses, it often appears that little attention is paid in designing the visuals to the intended use by students, i.e., artistic elements often triumph over meaningful pedagogy. The educational impact of these colorful graphics is also hard to measure as instructors may only implicitly refer to them without explicit instruction on their depth and meaning. This study focuses on the learning outcomes of students in an introductory physical science course for non-majors when explicit strategies are used to decode and deconstruct textbook visuals. Results are presented from various student assessments administered to experimental and control groups. Topics in mechanics (free fall) and astronomy (solar system) are discussed. This work has significance for the design of visuals to be used by scientific novices and the necessary instructional and assessment approaches that should accompany such use.
column19: *Supported by The Carnegie Academy for the Scholarship of Teaching & Learning and NASA grant #NCC-1-01055.

column5: Exploration of Brownian Motion Equation Using Video Capture*
column18: In 1828 Robert Brown investigated the random walk motion of tiny inert particles (pollen grains) as seen though a microscope. The cause of this random motion was explained by Einstein in a paper published in 1905. In that paper he derived an equation describing the motion of small particles as the result of being bombarded by even smaller (invisible) molecules. The results of this work were considered to be the first direct evidence for the existence of molecules and laid the foundations for the field of statistical mechanics. Jean-Baptiste Perrin verified Einstein's equation in 1908 in a series of painstaking experiments using latex spheres suspended in water. We have captured Brownian motion using video equipment and analyzed the motion on a computer using the motion analysis software Tracker (http://www.cabrillo.edu/~dbrown/tracker). The use of video equipment and computer analysis reduces the difficulty of the experiment to that of a good modern physics laboratory exercise for undergraduates.
column19: *The following students have contributed to this project: Rorie D. Hudson, Jeremy D. Schneider, Reese Salmon, and Canace E. Robbins. More information is available at http://physics.ius.edu

column5: Physics Education Research in Mexico
column18: In this talk we will present our work in three venues: a redesigned course, the implementation of tutorials, and the development of a training course for in-service teachers. We redesigned an introductory one-semester course in which the purpose is to help students to understand the connection between mathematical tools and physics concepts. We have implemented Tutorials for Introductory Physics in our university for about 2000 students taking three one-semester courses. We are going to present the process of the implementation including training sessions for course instructors and for undergraduate assistants. We also developed an innovative short course for in-service teachers based on Tutorials for Introductory Physics. The main objective of this training course is to provide in-service teachers with a first practical contact with an active learning teaching strategy. The course includes a tutorial session, a tutorial homework session, and a reflection and analysis of students' difficulties session.

column5: Demonstration of Air Drag Force During the Oscillatory Motion of a Variable Mass on a Spring Pendulum Using CBL Equipment*
column15: Rafael Digilov, Technion, Israel Institute of Tech.
column18: Computer based laboratory equipment was used to study an evolution of damped oscillations in variable mass on a spring pendulum. The mass was an inverted plastic soda bottle filled with sand and hung from the spring, which in turn was suspended from a force sensor connected trough DataLogger to PC. During oscillations the sand flakes off through an aluminum hopper screwed on bottleneck so that the pendulum mass was decreasing at steady state. To enhance the air resistance a thin wooden disk of 0.2m of diameter and 4 mm thickness was attached to the neck of the bottle. A mathematical model presented is based on the assumption that the damping is caused by air drag including linear and quadratic in the velocity damping terms and through the mass loss, excellent explains the observed decay in amplitude oscillations under different damping conditions.
column19: *Supported by the Israel Ministry of Absorption and Immigration.

column5: Seeing Roller Coasters, Jello, and Fiber Optics in a Different Light
column15: Heather L. Lunn, Univ. of Wisconsin--River Falls
column18: This summer I was on an internship in Washington D.C., and did some really cool "sciency" stuff. I was the coordinator of an all-girls camp. We built roller coasters out of K'Nex pieces and ran the roller coaster cars on test drives after I explained some of the physics behind the coasters. I also did a lesson on different sources and colors of light and how they differ when you look at them through diffraction grating ("rainbow") glasses. I also looked at how a red laser changed when it was pointed into jello, trying to obtain total internal reflection. Lastly, my lesson included fiber optics and their practical applications. I talked about how they can be made into the colorful Christmas trees, used for surgery and the internet. I also explained the idea behind how they work. I enjoyed working with all of the girls; it was great to see 13-year-olds interested in science and would love to talk about my outreach experience.

column5: Higher-State Relativity Theory
column15: Dompreh Kwadwo Anokye, Ghana Secondary School
column18: Unlike the theory of special relativity which uses the Lorentz -- Einstein set of transformation equations to prove that length contraction, time dilation and Doppler Effect occur in flat space-time, the General Theory of Relativity which deals with motion is a curved space-time has no such transformation equations. By using the concept of rotation and the curvature of light the transformation equations in curved space-time can be deduced and used to prove that Doppler Effect, length contraction and stellar aberration, as well as bending of sticks, occur in curved fields.

column5: Interferometric Studies of a Piano Soundboard
column18: Beginning with its development in the late seventeenth century, the piano has been extensively studied by musicians and scientists alike. Arguably, the most important part of a piano in determining the quality of the sound is the soundboard, which has been the subject of several scientific articles in recent years. We have investigated the vibrations of a piano soundboard interferometrically in order to better understand the factors which necessitate the peculiar shape and placement of the bridges. Additionally, we have developed a new method for measuring the driving point impedance in situ using measurements derived from real-time electronic speckle pattern interferometry. Interferograms will be presented that reveal some interesting dynamics of the piano soundboard during play, and new measurements of driving point impedances will be presented and analyzed.

column5: Examining Student Understanding of Electric Circuits*
column17: Peter S Shaffer, Lillian C McDermott
column18: As part of an ongoing investigation, the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington is continuing to examine student understanding of electric circuits. Several new research questions have been designed and administered to a variety of different populations, including undergraduates in introductory calculus-based courses, preservice teachers, and inservice K-12 teachers. In particular, we have been examining the relationship between the ability of students to incorporate an electrical element into a complete circuit and their knowledge of the element's internal construction. The results reinforce our findings from previous investigations that many students lack a functional understanding of a complete circuit. The insights we have gained from this research will be discussed in the context of specific examples.

column5: Mentoring that Makes a Difference: Improving K-12 Teaching Practice*
column17: Lezlie S. DeWater, Peter S. Shaffer, Lillian C McDermott
column18: The Physics Education Group at the University of Washington offers an intensive 6-week Summer Institute for inservice teachers. A primary goal is to help the participants acquire a deep understanding of topics relevant to the K-12 curriculum while learning through a process of inquiry

column17: Paula R.L Heron, Karen Wosilait, Lillian C McDermott
column18: The Physics Education Group at the University of Washington is developing research-based instructional materials on waves and physical optics. Results thus far indicate that the materials are effective with a variety of different populations. Materials under development for Physics by Inquiry,
