column18: Computing in Science and Engineering is publishing a four part comparative review of Maple, Mathematica, and MatLab. The first review is in the Jan/Feb 2005 issue of CiSE and you may download the reviews without charge. Please come and share your experiences with these scientific computational packages. Your comments are welcome and will improve the quality of the review articles.

column5: Improving the Understanding by Using the Video Materials
column15: Takuyuki Uragami, Okayama Univ. of Science
column18: The students mostly taken the physics at high school find difficulties in understanding the meaning of physics concepts expressed by using the derivatives and integrals in the introductory physics course at University level. They have so few occasions to experience the experiments on physics from their childhood to high school age. To connect the physics phenomena with mathematical expression in their minds, the video materials showing experiments are repeatedly used while the introduction of theoretical concepts, quantities, law and calculatins are in progress. The students abilities are measured by doing standard tests. The result of measurements and student's improvements will be discussed.

column5: Science Wall: A portable stereoscopic projection system for education and outreach.
column15: Phillip R Dukes, Univ. of Texas at Brownsville
column18: We will demonstrate and describe a portable low-cost stereoscopic projection system being used for general science education and outreach in the Brownsville, TX area. Our system is an adaptation of a passive 3D GeoWall using polarized light. Examples from planetary science and astronomy will be demonstrated.

column5: Combining Misconceptions with Symbolic Representations in Multiple Choice Distractors
column15: Edward Adelson, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: Multiple choice exam questions in which the distractors are not only based on misconceptions, but present answers in symbolic forms have been developed. Students may be offered a choice between force diagrams where forces are omitted or extra forces are present. Other problems ask for the equation at a beginning or intermediate stage, as well as at the final stage of the problem solution. The wrong equations may omit necessary terms or contain additional terms such as those that come from assuming retained impetus forces or both Newton?s third law forces on the same body. Examples will be given.

column5: Attracting Teachers to Regional SACS-AAPT Meeting using Workshops
column18: The Southern Atlantic Coast Section (SACS) of the American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT) is a growing regional organization with the purpose of bringing together physics teachers at all levels. We have traditionally had good representation from faculty at the 2-year and 4-year college levels, but have not been as successful at involving K12 teachers. We therefore wanted to reach out to physics and physical science teachers by providing a special program to bring them in contact with the organization, and to demonstrate the professional benefits of participation. With the help of a mini-grant from the national AAPT, teachers experienced a one-day workshop about modern physics. In this paper, we?ll discuss the workshop, and the important feedback we received concerning how we can best support teachers in our region, and our plans for expanding this program.
column19: This work supported by a grant from the AAPT National Office.

column5: NASA's Gravity Probe B Examines Einstein's Spacetime with Gyroscopes
column18: NASA's Gravity Probe B mission has been collecting data for four months to make the most precise measurement of the curvature of spacetime around the Earth. In addition, GP-B is testing the prediction of "frame-dragging" around the Earth. Frame-dragging is the idea the Earth's rotation causes the local spacetime frame to twist with it very slightly. GP-B is using the world's roundest gyroscopes to test this phenomenon and test Einstein's General Theory of Relativity. Results will be released in Summer 2006.

column5: Evaluating the Effect of Physlet-Based Experiences in the Introductory Physics Laboratory
column15: Adrienne Rodriguez-Zermeno, Univ. of Texas at Brownsville
column18: This presentation will cover research done in the algebra-based introductory physics laboratory. In one of the laboratory sections several traditional laboratory exercises were replaced with Physlet-based labs. Student?s performance on pre/post test assessment on these concepts was compared. This research is an extension of the research done by Anne J. Cox at Echerd College applying it to an open enrollment Hispanic serving institution.

column5: University of Wisconsin Oshkosh Master's of Physics Education Program
column15: Mark Lattery, Univ. of Wisconsin Oshkosh
column18: The University of Wisconsin Oshkosh will be launching a new Master's of Physics Education program in the Fall of 2005. Courses will be offered in physics content, pedagogy, and classroom technology. For more information, see the UWO Master's of Physics Education website: http://planck.phys.uwosh.edu/lattery/. This program will emphasize the ASU modeling method and be aligned to state and local science education standards.

column5: Build Your Own Model Rockets!
column18: The goal of this poster presentation is to provide physics teachers with an inexpensive, functional, and challenging model rocket project as an alternative to purchasing model rocket kits from a hobby store or supplier. Students can design and build their own model rockets using ordinary household items such as paper towel tubes, index cards, string, plastic bags, elastic, and cardboard. The rocket engines and construction supplies must be purchased. The poster presentation will illustrate the steps of building and designing model rockets through photographs, video, handouts, and a sample of a student-constructed rocket. Ideas for implementing, investigating, and launching model rockets (including safety precautions) will also be provided.

column5: An Interdisciplinary, Inquiry-based "Physics of Music" Course*
column18: The National Research Council calls for all students to learn science 'through methods and processes of inquiry.' To meet this challenge, we have developed an interdisciplinary, inquiry-based course, The Physics of Music, to serve humanities and social science students. The course is designed and taught by professors from the two disciplines of physics and music. We will discuss our preparation for and experiences of team-teaching, in addition to our students' responses to and progress in the course. We will present assessment data on student attitudes, and compare pretest and posttest results on several content questions. An example of an activity developed for the course will be included in the poster. *This project is supported by NSF DUE-0309942.
column19: Transforming Undergraduate Education in SMET, National Academy Press, Washington DC 1999

column5: Implementing "Physics by Inquiry" in Three Months
column15: Wally Axmann, Wichita State Univ., Physics Dept.
column18: Recent changes by our College of Education required the creation of an inquiry-based science course for education majors. Our department volunteered to create such a course based on McDermott's "Physics by Inquiry" materials. Work began in the spring semester of 2004, approximately three months before the course was to be offered. At that time, the department had very little laboratory equipment that was appropriate for this type of low-tech, hands-on course. To assist others with similar tasks, this paper will present the details of our implementation from design through two semesters of student usage. Implementation tasks, trials, and tips will be presented including course structure, equipment purchasing lists, and classroom organization. We will also discuss student and instructor perceptions of the course and ideas for future improvements.

column5: SPS, KC-135, and Other Acronyms of Note
column18: The presenter's goal is to tie together elements of this AAPT meeting including Society of Physics Students participation, the NASA/SPS/AAPT microgravity flight research awards being announced that evening (1/9/05), and student career development. Poster and discussion will cover experiences in these areas, and one example of a career path to which the Society of Physics Students contributed much support and positive influence.

column5: K-12 Physics Teachers Education and Training in Ethiopia
column18: Physics teachers training in Ethiopia is guided by the current educational policy of the country which states that teachers should be well-versed in their academic specialty, pedagogical sciences and professional ethics. Physics curricula take linearity at the second cycle of the primary school. In earlier grades its content is presented integrated with other sciences in the core subject of physical science. To teach conceptual, intermediate and college preparatory physics at different levels tertiary level physics education is required. The courses in physics education have components of teaching methodologies, curriculum design, developmental psychology and pre-service teaching training. The number of teachers meeting the standards of qualification is 97% in the first cycle of the primary education and 39% at the upper primary and secondary. To alleviate this problem in addition to the regular programs continuing education and distance learning are used as an option to improve the qualification of teachers.

column5: Academic Performance as a Function of Class Size in an Interactive Lab-based General Physics Course
column15: Lorraine Allen, U.S. Coast Guard Academy
column18: We explore the relationship between the number of students in a class and academic performance in an interactive laboratory-based general physics course. Each class meets approximately for two hours thrice a week or for three hours twice a week. Class size ranges from 15 to 25 students. Meetings consist of a brief lecture followed by immediate application of the material in hands-on laboratory experiments. Compared to the traditional lecture-based course, such an interactive approach to learning is expected to dramatically increase and deepen understanding of the concepts. Since students perform the experiments in groups consisting of 2 to 6 students, depending on class size, fewer students in a class allow an individual student more participation in a given experiment. While peer-interaction is intended to aid understanding in a lab-based course, a diminishing return in learning is expected as group size grows and individual students are engaged less in the experiments.
column19: CAPT Robert Fuller, a co-author on this poster, is an AAPT member.

column5: Networking Institutions Interested in the Preparation of Teachers of Science
column17: Warren W Hein, Jack G Hehn, Theodore Hodapp
column18: The American Association of Physics Teachers, American Physical Society and American Institute of Physics are collaborating in the formation of a network of colleges and universities who are active in the preparation of teachers of science, K-12. The poster will describe the organization and plan for the formation of this Coalition and provide information for those who wish to join.

column5: Photography as Physics in the Classroom
column18: A new technique of teaching and learning physics can be learnt derived from the scientist and artist Edgerton. Manipulating shudder speeds on cameras and frequencies of strobe light, pictures of different actions were taken by a high school physics class in Waltham, MA. Capturing the interplay of a tennis racket hitting a ball, the course of a dart hitting a balloon, the motility of a ball thrown straight up, the fall of a cracked egg, the motion of a thrown book, and the track of flapping arms using a camera and a strobe light allowed the class to actually see and take data on projectile motion, velocity, gravity, inertia, air resistance and pressure in a very educational as well as creative way. This poster exhibits some of the pictures taken by the class and explains the pictures' ability to show these aspects of science.

column5: Instruction of special relativity to college engineering students
column17: Robert J Culbertson, M. Colleen Megowan
column18: We are developing a reformed approach to teaching modern physics, beginning with special relativity, to university-level science and engineering students. A suite of student-centered inquiry-based tutorials has been created for use with small groups in a studio format. A Relativity Concept Inventory (RCI) was developed to access the effectiveness of these tutorials. An overview of these tutorials, the RCI, and preliminary results will be presented.

column5: Trebuchet Launches High School Students Into Engineering / Physics
column17: Chris Petta, Chris Williams, Ben Morhardt, Jauhar Kalid
column18: With the decreasing enrollment in the engineering / physics field in our nation today, we decided to take our Statics and Dynamics project, with the help of other SPS members, and transform it into a recruitment tool for the surrounding high schools. We invited over 300 high school students to a day at Highland Community College to give a presentation followed by throwing projectiles with our trebuchet. This project became apparent it would be an immediate success upon seeing the near 300 students attend our presentation and demonstration on Dec 10, 2004. Our goal was to increase the awareness of the physics program at not only Highland Community College, but the program across the nation. With the year of Einstein, we hoped that this would further inspire the young students to continue to pursue a career in Engineering Physics.
column19: Sponsor: Eric Peterson, Highland Comm. College

column5: Physics Workshops for the 21st Century Project*
column18: This poster paper will report on recent workshops and future workshops offered by this project for two-year college and high school physics teachers. This includes workshops on LabVIEW and LabPro; Physlets and HTML; TIPERs; Modeling; Microcomputer-Based Laboratories; Project-Based Physics; Investigative Science Learning Environment; and Introductory College Physics for the 21st Century. The goal of this project is to help TYC and HS physics students develop a stronger understanding of science, with an emphasis on physics and its applications in industry. These workshops are designed to acquaint the participants with the integration and implementation of emerging technology and active learning strategies. These workshops provide extensive and intensive, collaborative experiences for participants with workshop materials that make it easy for participants to implement the workshop ideas in their classroom.
column19: *Supported in part by ATE grant #0101589 from the National Science Foundation

column5: Physicists' Language about 'Force': An Alternative View of Students' Difficulties
column18: In this poster I will consider the the role of the concept of force in physics and the language used by physicists to describe it. I will present a) an analysis of the historical development of the idea of force and the language used to describe interactions and causality and b) a preliminary linguistic analysis of how modern physicists write about force and interactions. This analysis will be used to present an alternative hypothesis about some of the difficulties that students have with Newtonian mechanics. I will then examine some of the 'misconceptions' literature concerning the concept of force and argue that some of students? so-called 'misconceptions' may be better understood from this alternative perspective.

column5: Using Java 3D for Magnetospheric Visualization in Space Weather Classes
column18: Our understanding of the world around us is often a process of developing increasingly sophisticated models to account for available data. Improvements in technology enable us to discover more every year and scientists work to create models of understanding that reflect new and additional information. Communicating this very process effectively to our students is extremely challenging and we often fail in this endeavor. This paper will discuss the use of CALCHAS to teach physics, space science, and astronomy through an understanding of Space Weather. CALCHAS is a 3D visualization package that integrates models and data and is used in data assimilation schemes in Space Weather forecasting. The package is written in Java 3D, and has a modular design, so that different models and datasets, both real-time and historical, can be seamlessly compared using a variety of goodness-of-fit measures. Using this technology in teaching not only provides students with an opportunity to explore concepts through a concrete application (space weather forecasting), but it also gives them an opportunity to explore it in a manner similar to that used by research scientists. The package is used both in research and education at the undergraduate level.

column5: Influence of Qualitative Physics Exam Questions on MCAT Scores
column18: The current format for the MCAT puts a greater emphasis on passeges with multiple questions (about 84%) versus stand-alone questions (16%). The passages are designed to measure analytical reasoning,abstract thinking and problem solving. Less emphasis is placed on content based questions. Students who take either calculus or algebra based physics must answer qualitative questions which accounts for 33% of each exam. We find that students who do well on qualitative and conceptual questions tend to do well on the physical science section of the MCAT. We have also started to look at FCI scores and how well they correlate to student success using qualitative reasoning skills on physics exams.

column5: The Atoms Family: You Too Can Teach Nuclear Science!
column18: The power of the atom was harvested in nuclear energy over sixty years ago and currently supplies approximately 20% of the nation?s electricity needs with 103 operating American reactors. Despite widespread use, knowledge about the technology involved remains an enigma to a vast portion of the general population. Like any technology, there are costs and benefits to application, but in the nuclear energy field, the general lack of understanding and fear of radiation hazards magnify the risks and fail to acknowledge the benefits. The benefits of reducing environmental effects of electricity production and dependency on foreign fossil fuels are often overshadowed by Chernobyl inspired nuclear fervor. Irrational fear is effectively countered by education practices focused on the presentation of material in an unbiased approach at an appropriate skill level. An interactive curriculum on nuclear energy and the basics of radiation are appropriate for any age level (even politicians!) and is the only means to establishing a nuclear future. As a teacher, YOU can help secure the nuclear future of the U.S.!

column5: Magnetism Kits for the Introductory Classroom
column18: As part of curricular materials that are under development for the college-based introductory course, magnetism kits have been assembled for student use both in and out of the classroom. Materials for the kits were selected to keep costs down (~$20 per kit), to provide a variety of magnetic activities, and to showcase how many everyday items can be used to explore the properties of magnetism. A listing of the materials and sample activities will be presented. The kits will be beta tested this Spring semester, with the results presented at a future AAPT meeting.

column5: Astronomy 101: A Service Course?
column15: Carrie Wallace*, Southern Illinois Univ. Edwardsville
column18: Astronomy 101 is often taught with instructors covering whatever material they wish. However, we may need to start teaching it as a service course for pre-service science teachers. In the state of Illinois, astronomy is an integral part of the state science standards and pre-service teachers must demonstrate mastery of the content prior to student teaching. To meet this need, SIUE now requires all secondary science education majors to take our equivalent of Astronomy 101. To determine how common this is, we conducted a study to investigate the prevalence of astronomy in each state's science standards, as well as how each state evaluates mastery of the content. In addition, we looked at what type of institutions' pre-service typically take astronomy. In this talk we will present the results from this study, as well as the implications of teaching astronomy 101 as a service course for pre-service science teachers.
